Zou 1   Using an electron-positron collision data sample of 2.93 fb −1 collected at a center-of-mass energy of √ s = 3.773 GeV with the BESIII detector, we present the first search for the radiative leptonic decay D + → γe + νe.
The analysis is performed with a double tag method.

We do not observe a significant D + → γe + νe signal, and obtain an upper limit on the branching fraction of D + → γe + νe decay with the energy of radiative photon larger than 10 MeV of 3.0 × 10 −5 at the 90% confidence level.
PACS numbers: 13.20.Fc, 12.39.St
I. INTRODUCTION

In contrast to the purely leptonic decay, the radiative leptonic decay of the charged charmed meson, D + → γe + ν e , is not subject to the helicity suppression rule due to the presence of a radiative photon.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: With no finalstate hadron, treatment of the non-perturbative strong interaction effects in theoretical calculations is relatively simple.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The radiative leptonic decays of heavy mesons have been studied with various models [1][2][3][4].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Within the perturbative quantum chromodynamics (pQCD) approach, the branching fraction of D + → γe + ν e decay is predicted to be of order 10 −4 [1].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Much smaller branching fractions, of order 10 −6 , are obtained within the light front quark model [2] and the non-relativistic constituent quark model [3].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In Ref.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: [4], the long-distance contribution is considered via the vector meson dominance (VMD) model and it is found that the decay rate may be enhanced significantly.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: To deal with non-perturbative effects, it is important to separate the hard and soft physics, typically with an approach known as factorization.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Many approaches to factorization of the radiative leptonic decays of heavy mesons have been proposed [5][6][7][8][9][10][11].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In recent papers [12,13], factorization is extended to consider the first-order corrections in the strong coupling constant α s and the heavy quark mass; the branching fraction of D + → γe + ν e decay is predicted to be of order 10 −5 .
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In this paper, we present the first search for the decay D + → γe + ν e , based on a data sample of 2.93 fb −1 [14,15] collected with the BESIII detector at a center-of-mass energy √ s = 3.773 GeV.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: No obvious signal is observed, and an upper limit on the branching fraction of D + → γe + ν e decay is set at the 90% confidence level (C.L.).

THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET
The BESIII detector is a general purpose spectrometer with a geometrical acceptance of 93% of 4π.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: It consists of a main drift chamber (MDC) for measuring the momentum and specific ionization of charged particles in a 1 T solenoidal magnetic field, a time of flight (TOF) system to perform particle identification, and a CsI(Tl) electromagnetic calorimeter (EMC) for measurement of deposited shower energies.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: These components are surrounded by a multi-layer resistive plate counter system, which is designed to identify the muons.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: A detailed description of the BESIII detector can be found in Ref.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET
II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: High-statistics Monte Carlo (MC) simulated data samples are used to determine the detection efficiency and to estimate potential background contamination.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: A geant4-based [17] MC simulation program is used to simulate the interactions of particles in the spectrometer and the detector response.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: For the production of ψ(3770), kkmc [18] is used; it includes the effects of beam energy spread and initial-state radiation (ISR).
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: The known decay modes are generated using evtgen [19,20] according to branching fractions from the Particle Data Group (PDG) [21], and the remaining unknown decay modes are simulated by lundcharm [22].
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: Final-state radiation (FSR) of charged tracks is incorporated with photos [23].
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: In modeling the signal events, the approach of Ref.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: [12] is adopted, where first-order effects in the strong coupling constant α s and the heavy quark mass are considered.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: The minimum energy of the radiative photon is set at 10 MeV to avoid the infrared divergence for soft photons.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: For D + → π 0 e + ν e decay, which is an important background, an exclusive MC sample is generated by adopting the associated form-factor model and parameters in Ref.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET
II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: The analysis uses a double-tag (DT) technique [25] which exploits the exclusive DD final states produced near threshold in e + e − experiments.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: This technique allows one to measure absolute decay branching fractions of D + mesons independent of any direct knowledge of the total number of D + D − events.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: In this analysis, the D − candidates, so-called single-tag (ST) events, are reconstructed through six specific hadronic decay modes
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: The signal D + → γe + ν e is then searched for among the remaining tracks and showers recoiling against the ST D − candidates; such signal candidate events are denoted as double-tag (DT) events.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: The absolute branching fraction, B(D + → γe + ν e ), can be obtained from the ratio of the DT yields and the ST yields,
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: where N DT is the sum of signals yields for all tag modes and N i ST , ε i DT and ε i ST are the ST yields and the detection efficiencies of DT and ST for ST mode i, respectively.
body_text.section: II. THE BESIII DETECTOR AND DATA SET

body_text.text: With this approach, the systematic uncertainties in the ST selection reconstruction are largely canceled in the branching fraction measurement.

body_text.text: A. Single-Tag event selection and yields

For each charged track, we require the polar angle θ in the MDC to satisfy | cos θ| < 0.93 and the point of the closest approach to the interaction point (IP) of the e + e − beams to be within 1 cm in the plane perpendicular to the beam (V r ) and within ±10 cm along the beam axis (V z ).
body_text.section: A. Single-Tag event selection and yields

body_text.text: Particle identification (PID) for charged tracks is accomplished by combining the information on the measured ionization energy loss (dE/dx) in the MDC and the flight time in the TOF into a PID likelihood, L(h), for each hadron hypothesis h = K or h = π.
body_text.section: A. Single-Tag event selection and yields

body_text.text: The π (K) candidates are required to satisfy
body_text.section: A. Single-Tag event selection and yields

body_text.text: The K 0 S candidates are reconstructed from combinations of two tracks with opposite charge which satisfy | cos θ| < 0.93 and |V z | < 20 cm, but with no V r and no PID requirements.
body_text.section: A. Single-Tag event selection and yields

body_text.text: The K 0 S candidates must have an invariant mass in the range 0.487 < M π + π − < 0.511 GeV/c 2 , corresponding to three times our mass resolution.
body_text.section: A. Single-Tag event selection and yields

body_text.text: To reject combinatorial background, we further require the decay length of K 0 S candidates, the distance between the IP and the reconstructed secondary decay vertex provided by a vertex fit algorithm, to be larger than two standard deviations.

body_text.section: A. Single-Tag event selection and yields

SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES
The systematic uncertainties in the selection of the ST candidates are assumed to largely cancel, with any residual effects being negligible.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: Other systematic uncertainties, related to the detection efficiencies, are summarized in Table III.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: To evaluate the systematic uncertainty related to the model of the decay dynamics, an alternative signal MC sample based on the single pole model [1,12] is produced, and the resultant difference in the detection efficiency with respect to the nominal value, 3.5%, is assigned as the systematic uncertainty.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The uncertainties of electron tracking and PID are estimated to be 0.5% and 0.5%, respectively, by studying a control sample of radiative Bhabha scattering events.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The uncertainty in photon reconstruction is assigned as 1.0%, based on a study of double-tagged D 0 → K S π 0 events [28].
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The uncertainty related with the lateral moment requirement for the photon is estimated to be 4.4% by studying a photon control sample from radiative Bhabha scattering events.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The quadratic sum of the above systematic uncertainties, related to detection efficiency, is 5.8%.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The systematic uncertainty associated with the estimated number of background D + → π 0 e + ν e events includes a statistical uncertainty on the size of the DT control sample (D + → π 0 e + ν e ) of 2.3%, and relative uncertainties on the detection efficiency relative to signal, of 1.0% for the π 0 1C kinematic fit, and 1.0% for the extra photon with respect to the signal.
body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: Adding in quadrature, the total uncertainty of the background D + → π 0 e + ν e rate is 2.7%.

body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.section: IV. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: V. THE UPPER LIMIT ON BRANCHING FRACTION
To set the upper limit on the decay branching fraction B(D + → γe + ν e ), we follow the method in Refs.
body_text.section: V. THE UPPER LIMIT ON BRANCHING FRACTION

body_text.text: [28,29] which takes into account the effects of both systematic and statistical uncertainties.
body_text.section: V. THE UPPER LIMIT ON BRANCHING FRACTION

body_text.text: We obtain a smooth probability density function (PDF) from the data sample using the kernel estimation method [30].
body_text.section: V. THE UPPER LIMIT ON BRANCHING FRACTION

body_text.text: A large number of toy MC samples are generated according to the smooth PDF, while the number of events in each MC sample is allowed to fluctuate with a Poisson distribution according to the yield found in the fit to the data sample.
body_text.section: V. THE UPPER LIMIT ON BRANCHING FRACTION

body_text.text: The same fit procedure used for data is applied to each toy MC sample, while randomly making systematic variations in the fit procedure, as described in the previous section.
body_text.section: V. THE UPPER LIMIT ON BRANCHING FRACTION

body_text.text: In the calculation of the branching fraction B(D + → γe + ν e ) for the toy MC sample, the DT efficiencies are varied randomly according to the detection efficiency uncertainties (5.8%), and the ST yields and the corresponding efficiencies are varied randomly according to the statistical uncertainty due to the size of data and MC samples.

body_text.text: VI.
SUMMARY

In summary, we present the first search for the radiative leptonic decay D + → γe + ν e in the charm sector based on a DT method using a data sample of 2.93 fb −1 collected with the BESIII detector at a center-of-mass energy √ s = 3.773 GeV.
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: No significant D + → γe + ν e signal is observed.
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: With a 10 MeV cutoff on the radiative photon energy, the upper limit of the decay branching fraction for D + → γe + ν e is B(D + → γe + ν e ) < 3.0 × 10 −5 at the 90% C.L. The result approaches the theoretical predictions in Refs.
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: [12,13]; more data may help to discriminate among the full suite of theoretical models.
